Question_1.Context: The study discusses the fabrication of porous nanocomposites for adsorption of environmental contaminants.
Question_1.Question: What is the main advantage of using lignosulfonate (LS) in the fabrication of the porous nanocomposites?
Question_1.Source: The dual role of LS enhanced the equilibrium adsorption capacity of the composites, which increased from 50 mg/g to 66 mg/g for the non-functionalized and LS-functionalized nGO1-Gel1-LS0.1 composites, respectively.

Question_2.Context: The study focuses on the adsorption performance of the composites towards heavy metal ions.
Question_2.Question: What was the equilibrium adsorption capacity of the LS-functionalized nGO1-Gel1-LS0.1 composite for Cu(II) ions?
Question_2.Source: The LS-functionalized composites demonstrated good reusability through a mild regeneration step, with 79% retention of the adsorption capacity after five adsorption-desorption cycles.

Question_3.Context: The study explores the adsorption behavior of the composites towards cationic dyes.
Question_3.Question: What was the adsorption capacity of the LS-functionalized composite for methylene blue?
Question_3.Source: Apart from heavy metal ions, the potential for cationic dye adsorption was also demonstrated as the LS-functionalized composite exhibited an adsorption capacity of 38 mg/g for methylene blue.

Question_4.Context: The study discusses the recyclability of the composite adsorbent.
Question_4.Question: After five cycles of Cu(II) adsorption-desorption, what percentage of the adsorption capacity was retained by the composite?
Question_4.Source: The sample was found to retain 79% of its adsorption capacity after the fifth cycle.

Question_5.Context: The study highlights the fabrication process of the porous nanocomposites.
Question_5.Question: What method was employed to construct the three-dimensional (3D) free-standing porous composites?
Question_5.Source: The abundant oxygen functionalities on nGO conferred the construction of porous composites possessing three-dimensional (3D) interconnected network structure through the self-assembly of hydrogels using only gelatin as a crosslinker, coupled by freeze-drying method.

Question_6.Context: The study investigates the adsorption behavior of the composites towards heavy metal ions.
Question_6.Question: What was the equilibrium time required for the LS-functionalized nGO1-Gel1-LS0.1 composite to reach maximum adsorption capacity for Cu(II) ions?
Question_6.Source: The LS-functionalized composites demonstrated good reusability through a mild regeneration step, with 79% retention of the adsorption capacity after five adsorption-desorption cycles.

Question_7.Context: The study discusses the fabrication process of the porous nanocomposites.
Question_7.Question: What was used as a crosslinker in the self-assembly of the hydrogels to construct the porous composites?
Question_7.Source: The abundant oxygen functionalities on nGO conferred the construction of porous composites possessing three-dimensional (3D) interconnected network structure through the self-assembly of hydrogels using only gelatin as a crosslinker, coupled by freeze-drying method.

Question_8.Context: The study discusses the adsorption performance of the composites towards heavy metal ions.
Question_8.Question: What was the main mechanism that governed the adsorption of positively charged Cu(II) ions by the LS-functionalized composites?
Question_8.Source: Electrostatic interactions were assumed to be the mechanism that governed the adsorption of positively charged Cu(II) ions by nGO and LS with negatively charged oxygen-containing functional groups and sulfonate groups.

Question_9.Context: The study explores the adsorption behavior of the composites towards cationic dyes.
Question_9.Question: Besides electrostatic forces, what other interactions were reported to govern the adsorption of methylene blue by graphene-based carbon materials?
Question_9.Source: Besides electrostatic forces, the adsorption of MB by graphene-based carbon materials has been reported to also be governed by π-π stacking interactions and hydrogen bonding.

Question_10.Context: The study discusses the fabrication process of the porous nanocomposites.
Question_10.Question: What was the method employed to derive nanographene oxide (nGO) from lignosulfonate-derived carbon spheres (CS)?
Question_10.Source: nGO was synthesized by oxidation of lignosulfonate-derived carbon spheres (CS), that were obtained through an acid-catalyzed microwave-assisted carbonization process adapted from previous work.
